ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course will definitely aid in development in Excel skills and how to read financial statements. This is a practical course for finance, banking, etc prospectives.
Accounting skills
Basics of Accounting and understanding financial statements
How to use excel workbooks
Basic introduction into accounting and corporate accounting methods.
I learned about the three types of financial statements and how they work.
I learned a basic amount of accounting, how to do journal entries, and gained increased familiarity with the three financial statements and 10-Ks.
not even the fundamentals of accounting
Interpreting financial statements, completing financial statements
A basis understanding of accounting
Time value of money, bond valuation, double entry accounting, basic discounted cash flows, three statement model.
Basic accounting knowledge
I learned about the fundamentals of accounting and valuation.
I broadened my knowledge on various concepts such as present value. I also learned more about the 3 types of financial statements and how to make journal entries/analyze them.
If you are interested in the field of accounting for finance as a future career path this class is great, otherwise it may not be for you.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I feel that from part 1 to part 2, the course-load dramatically increased. The difficulty of the topics increased almost too dramatically, so much so I lost the ability to continue to follow along.
Interesting and useful class material
Not a lot of homework assignments to really grasp the material but grading system was lenient.
Learning more outside of the excel sheets would be really useful

Strengths - Prof. Antle does genuinely care about you learning this stuff. If you have the desire to learn accounting, he'll go above and beyond to make sure you get it. 

Weaknesses - Lectures were a bit unorganized, and I found the course canvas a bit hard to navigate (I didn't realize there were readings until the end of the semester). Mostly user error, I'm sure, but the website and the class itself were just kind of complicatedly structured. I ended up Credit D'ing the class just to avoid taking the final on the 21st.
Better organization and clearer communication with the instructor would be helpful. I was often confused by due dates since the timeline on canvas didn't match the pace materials were being covered
Strengths: lots of online resources available to help me with the assignments. Weaknesses: not always very clear instructions on assignments and how to go about completing them.

Professor Antle created a great Excel program to help teach us accounting. However, I wish that he had gone through each line item in the journal in a more traditional lecture style where we learn where to find it. Instead, he taught by providing a large amount of ungraded practice, which I did not find facilitated much learning for me.

you have to go to lectures to understand how to do practice problems.
prof would give out these assignments without any guidance and expect us to know how to do them.
he never explained what an accounts receivable is which i think is a good gauge as to how this course was taught.

This course focuses a lot on applying Excel skills in accounting settings. It was interesting and potentially useful, but took at least two weeks of stumbling through the assignments until I really felt comfortable with it. I understand the "learning by working through it" approach, but I felt that I was only really understanding the "how" and not the "why" of the material.
The homeworks were incredibly well thought out and helpful. I also appreciated the opportunity to review the homeworks together as a class.
I'll be honest, an 8:40am class at SOM can be pretty tough sometimes and I think that caused the low attendance at lecturers. But other than that, amazing professor and teaching style.

I have a little bit of accounting experience. I think we could have learned more about schedules, like PP&E. I think this course could really improve if we learned how to make revenue assumptions and project out and income statement and then use that to build a dcf.
Great course
I really appreciate how we were given a key to check our homework, specifically, the use of the accounting tool was extremely helpful.

This course was very organized and methodical, which I found very helpful going in with no accounting background. One possible weakness is lectures being recorded as it allowed students to miss class.
The first half of the class with valuation was extremely interesting, the content could have done with more diversity in accounting side as it felt very repetitive.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course will definitely aid in development in Excel skills and how to read financial statements. This is a practical course for finance, banking, etc prospectives.
Yes, very useful for many careers.
If you want to learn the basics of accounting

I'm not sure where I stand with this course. At least half of my time spent working on problems was trying to fix issues with the excel sheets (tabs moving, trying to figure out why my answer was "wrong" only to realize that I did not have the numbers in the order that the sheet was programmed to mark as correct). From this perspective, I think I spent a lot of time on this course but did not necessarily learn a lot of accounting.

Yes, basic accounting proficiency is certainly a good skill to have. The class gives you a decent financial vocabulary - which is good for whatever industry you go into. Every company has "Accounts Receivable".
Yes. If you're looking for a good introduction into accounting that students at other technical undergraduate finance institutions have this is it.
No, waste of time. Youtube teaches it better.
You get out of this course however much you put into it. If you want to learn the basics of accounting and put in the effort to complete the assignments, sure why not take this course.

I wanted to learn more accounting before beginning a career in finance, so I thought that this course would be helpful. I still think that any student looking to do so would do well in this course. However, the professor mostly provided practice instead of teaching new concepts, and nothing was graded, so I do not feel like I took away as much as I would have liked to.
no. having the summer as past accounting experience, had I not learned the basics then, I would have been absolutely lost in this class. if you need a guy this is the place to go.
Yes. This course was a very nice introduction to accounting. I learned what I hoped to in a fairly painless environment!
Yes
Yes. Professor is great. Accounting is a dry subject but prof Antle is funny and makes it fun.
I would recommend this course to any pursuing a degree in finance, as you learn many relevant concepts, such as financial statements, bond pricing, and more.

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to other students interested in an intro level accounting course or interested in broadening their understanding of basic accounting concepts. It teaches you skills that are very applicable in the real world.
Sure, if this is something you are interested in.
